title: Why do highly intelligent people tend to have less friends? - Quora

response.answer_text: From childhood to Adulthood I pretty much never really had friends. Childhood nada! Friendship lasted on average 3 months only didn’t make my first friend till 7th grade, and it only lasted 3 months. High School I was hanging out with my cousins college friends but school I was pretty much alone and pretty much one the handful of kids with no friends. Early Adulthood: First job yanked! I was yanked away and wasn’t allowed to hangout with my peer group. I didn’t do good in school and academics, and I knew I was stupid. So I didn’t understand why I was yanked out and not allowed to be around the other people at work. If I went near someone in my peer group to socialize I was immediately stopped. At 18 years old I was only allowed to socialize with people 24 and up, and the adults controlled my social circle. They knew why I didn’t. I still don’t get how people with average IQ’s get jobs so easily. I get rejected by almost every single job I apply for. I know people who have 3 jobs a year and I struggle to get 1. It’s not like having an high IQ pays off for everything. Life Statistics: I have less than 1% of getting along with someone If I do get along with someone it’s 75% chance they’re at least 10 years old than I’ am. It takes 3 years for people to understand me and see how I think. I don’t think like everyone else and I struggle to do their social interactions. If you have friends and you’re out socializing it’s simple enough for your friends to say “Nice try I saw what you’re trying to do!” and enjoy that moment. If you’re doing something that’s not simple they pretty much don’t know what the hell happened or what you’re trying to do and it just ends up in an ugly and toxic debate. about 98% of social interaction I’m looking around waiting for their next action and you can see their next move. It’s too much work to socialize it’s the same patterns and countering the negatives. I talk to a sort of loner baby boomer scientist and I enjoy talking to him because I see him countering the negatives he has around 33 Gestures Per Minute with out having to fully animate and freeze frame using body language. Like an “I don’t know.” isn't shrug shoulder freeze..freeze…freeze…wait get acknowledgement unfreeze gesture.

Frankly speaking, it’s because most people are intolerably boring and repulsively dumb. And you meant to say “fewer” friends, not “less.” See how I am? I’m truly sorry I feel that way, sorry I am this way; I think it’s likely a defect and a character flaw of mine, but witnessing extreme stupidity and bungling physically nauseates me, while witnessing the expression of intelligence and competence gives me pleasure and satisfaction. I can’t change that; it’s as involuntary as any other physical reflex. I don’t mean to hate you or get disgusted by your incompetence. It just happens. And I guess even if I smile and try to hide it, it shows. Sorry. I’m not among the smartest by any means, but even for me, it’s hard to do anything remotely normal. Normal life is just so fucking stupid, bass-ackwards, and genuinely, truly, literally, retarded. In a technical sense. Held back. Not advanced. I can’t sit there and pretend to be interested while my obese cousin discusses the pasta prices at various supermarkets in great detail. I physically can’t stand it, and I suppose it shows on my face. Yes, the combination of obesity and obsession with pasta prices triggers me. I want to vomit. Is that because I’m smart, mentally ill, an asshole, or some combination of the three? Can those three ever be teased apart? I do not know. What I know is, people often get offended at my rudeness and I often hate spending time with them, so why do it again? Invites dwindle, to mutual relief. Alone, I’m free. I can read, think, and write at my own speed. I can do three or four things at once, or focus on what I want, for as long as I need to. Talking is so very slow, at best. Talking to stupid people is intolerable, and I avoid it whenever possible. They avoid me in return, which is certainly fair enough. I’ve had few friends, and they’re mostly all dead now. I’d like to say that I’d trade it all for more friends, but I guess I wouldn’t, after all. I’d like a few more friends and I’d like better friends, but so far, they’ve been few and far between. C’est la vie. YMMV.
